Description: Large fragment of plate, carved from black and greyish olive hard stone, likely serpentine; preserved complete profile with wide and shallow shape with a flat outward rim and delineated base; smooth outer and inner surfaces.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Redpath Museum, Montreal. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Serpentine is particularly used in the early history of stone vessel's production in Egypt and rarely after the New Kingdom. The type of serpentine used for this plate, opaque olive green in colour with black veins, have a long range of use and is attested from the Predynastic until the New Kingdom (Aston 1994, 59, type A serpentine). The shape in itself looks late however, possibly Late or Ptolemaic periods. Bar the three fragments of vessel in serpentine, all kept in Montreal Redpath Museum (2469.1-3), Naukratis provided a few weights and tools in serpentine (or alleged to be serpentine). Aston, B. G. 1994, Ancient Egyptian stone vessels: materials and forms, Heidelberg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (EA.157) (phase 3)
